'A PROPOSAL TO RELOCATE THE NATIONAL EDUCATIONAL RADIO NETWORK
FROM URBANA, ILLINOIS TO WASHINGTON, D. C.
Background
The National Educational Radio Tape Network (NERN) began in
1950 as an innovation in the mass use of tape recorded programs
Its headquarters on the campus of the University of Illinois
has, for the past eighteen years, acted as a clearinghouse
for the selection, mass duplication and distribution of pro¬
gram material produced for educational radio stations.
When the National Association of Educational Broadcasters
moved its headquarters from Urbana to Washington, D. C. in
1960, the network offices and duplicating facility remained
in Urbana.
The Board of Directors of National Educational Radio (sup¬
ported by the NAEB Board of Directors) has taken the position
that, when feasible, the network offices plus duplicating and
distribution facilities should be relocated to Washington, D. C
Financial resources have not been available.
Proposal
That the Corporation for Public Broadcasting provide funds
to support relocating the network facilities. Operation in
Washington, D. C. would begin July 1, 1969. To expedite the
plan described in detail below, a decision to fund should be
made prior to March 31, 1969.
Justification
The network should be relocated for the following reasons:
1. Efficiency. The network is housed in two
buildings (separated by an intervening structure)
on the University of Illinois campus. The
present quarters are two old residences. Neither
was designed for the present function. The fact
that duplicating activity is housed in one build¬
ing and the traffic and clerical functions in a
